Hosting the stars of a former TV comedy sit-com so they can banter and wise-crack might seem an odd way to promote the benefits of college. 
But Wednesday night at the Taylor campus of Wayne County Community College, an almost-capacity crowd of about 300 parents, students and student-wannabes rose to clap and cheer after hearing stars of the former hit show “A Different World” blend humor with a nudge for all to seek higher education. 
“I’m absolutely going back,” said college drop-out Kyle Garrett, 21, of Ecorse, after the event. He’d seen "A Different World" in re-runs, but after hearing the stars talk up higher ed, “now I’m really looking at the show with a new view,” Garrett said. 
Related: Reports: George and Amal Clooney are expecting twins 
Although the comedy's six-season run ended in 1993, it's still drawing laughs in reruns on cable TV and Netflix. "A Different World," a spin-off of “The Cosby Show,” was a likeable riff on the quirky rewards of college life at an imaginary, mostly black Hillman College. 
In person, the actors who spoke in Taylor — Darryl Bell, who played Ron Johnson; Jasmine Guy, a star of the show in her role as Whitley Gilbert; Kadeem Hardison, whose was known for his flip-up spectacles in the role of Dwayne Wayne; and Charnelle Brown, who played the studious Kimberly Reese — were making one stop in a multi-city tour aimed at getting young African Americans thinking about going to college, according to a news release. Part of the message was that black youths should consider one of the nation’s the historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) that were models for the TV show. The onstage dialogue Wednesday was moderated by Detroit radio talk show host Mildred Gaddis of WCHB 1200 AM. 
HCBUs formed mainly in the aftermath of the Civil War, when blacks were not allowed to attend white colleges and universities. Although HCBUs now are integrated — some have more students of other races than black students — they’re still a great option for African Americans considering higher education, said LaTosha Walker, 37, of Grosse Pointe Woods. 
Former "A Different World" actor Darryl Bell, right, speaks during a "It's A Different World College Forum" on Wednesday, Feb. 8, 2017 at Wayne County Community College in Taylor. Cast members from the TV sitcom reunited to tour college campuses to discuss the show's current relevance and legacy. (Photo: Rachel Woolf, Special to the Free Press) 
“You hear now that the need for historically black colleges no longer exists” but that’s not true, said Walker, who majored in chemical engineering at North Carolina A&T State University in Greensboro, N.C. 
Going there was "empowering," Walker said. "Your professors look like you. The chancellor looks like you. You say to yourself, ‘What do you know? — a black person can run a college,’ and you don't get that anywhere else,” Walker said. She attended Wednesday’s event to gain insights about choosing colleges for her six children and step-children, ages 2 through 21, she said. 
The popularity of "A Different World" has been credited by some college presidents for increasing enrollment numbers at HBCUs during the years the show originally aired. 
With college graduation rates of African Americans lagging behind those of white students, educators are eager to enroll more blacks in college, said Mawine Diggs, vice chancellor of student services for Wayne County Community College District. Historically black colleges traditionally offered “a strong support system — people looked out for you and noticed if you didn’t go to class,” Diggs said. 
“Now, society has changed and these colleges do have white students — they’re very blended — but I still think they have a lot to offer,” she said. 
In 2015, a Gallup poll found that black students at HCBUs were twice as likely as black students at other colleges to receive three key supports — a professor who excited them about learning; an effective mentor; and a feeling that their teachers cared about them. 
On stage Wednesday, the ex-cast members told college aspirants that just as important as choosing a college was choosing the attitude to go with it. 
As a college freshman, for example, "You have to decide if you're going to be the type of person who's on time — because if you don't show up on time, you may not be back," Guy told the audience. 
The jovial group chatted about a lot more than college 101, however, including tattoos, body image, what each gender finds attractive in the other, and how relationships have changed since the show was filmed. Back in the day, alluding to her on-screen character, “I never believed he was a gigolo,” quipped Guy, bantering with Hardison, as he threw back his head in laughter. 
Contact Bill Laitner: blaitner@freepress.com.
